Award.AwardTitle: Analysis, Algorithm Design, and Computation for Stochastic Systems and Optimization
Award.AbstractNarration:
Motivated by emerging applications, this proposal encompasses several research topics in systems theory and stochastic optimization methods. (1) It aims to develop new stochastic approximation algorithms (with delays, distributed processors, and a switching process representing the random environment). Asymptotic properties of these algorithms and related limit results will be established. The results can be applied to consensus control problems among others. (2) Stability of systems with random delays (possibly due to communication latency) will be investigated. Sufficient conditions for stability of nonlinear systems and criteria for functional differential systems with random delays will be obtained. The expected results will shed more lights on treating stability of systems that are delay dependent. (3) Error estimates in the form of large deviations for system identification using regular and quantized observations will be obtained. By considering both space complexity in terms of quantization and time complexity with respect to data window sizes, this study focuses on providing a better understanding to the fundamental relationship between probabilistic errors and resources that represent data sizes in algorithms, sample sizes in analysis, and channel bandwidths in communications. (4) To approximate the first exit time for diffusions, Markov chain approximation methods will be developed and their rates of convergence will be obtained. To treat numerical solutions to stochastic differential equations with continuous-state-dependent switching, pathwise rates of convergence will be ascertained using a sequence of re-embedded numerical solutions having the same distribution as the original systems in an enlarged probability space.

This project aims to bridge systems theory, stochastic optimization methods, and applications. The research topics proposed include developing iterative algorithms using parallel processors and taking random environment into consideration, investigating stability of systems involving random delays, obtaining lower and upper estimation error bounds for system identification under different observation patterns, and designing and analyzing numerical solutions of problem involving certain differential equations with random uncertainty. The problems to be studied have been extracted from or motivated by real applications. It is anticipated that the results of this research will be useful for applications in networked systems, wireless communication, financial engineering, system identification with regular and quantized observations, and numerical solutions of certain problems involving random differential equations. The models to be constructed, the intrinsic properties of the systems, and the numerical methods and algorithms to be developed will lead to potential transfer of advances in stochastic systems theory and optimization methods to the aforementioned applications. Theproposed research will involve participation of graduate students; it will also include undergraduate student research projects. By integrating the proposed research with teaching and student training, the planned work will contribute to the further development of mathematical systems theory and the improvement of mathematics education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
a. Describe the project outcomes or findings that address the intellectual merit and broader impacts of the work as defined in the NSF merit review criteria.


This project aimed to bridge systems theory, optimizationmethods, and applications when random disturbances have to be taken into consideration. The research topics includeddeveloping algorithms using parallel processors andtaking random environment into consideration, investigatingstability of systems involving random delays, obtaining lower andupper estimation error bounds for system identification underdifferent observation patterns, and designing and analyzingnumerical solutions of problem involving certain differentialequations with random uncertainty. The problems studied havebeen extracted and abstracted from or motivated by real applications.

Concentrating on the mathematical modeling, analysis, and computational algorithm design, the results of this research will be useful for applications in wireless communication (e.g., wireless communication among autonomous vehicles), networked systems (e.g., social networks), financial engineering and insurance risk management, system identification with regular and quantized observations (e.g., battery diagnosis, medical signal processing, electric machines in electric vehicles), and numerical solutions of problems involving random differential equations. The models constructed, the intrinsic properties of the systems, and thenumerical methods and algorithms developed will lead topotential transfer of advances in mathematical theory andoptimization methods to the aforementioned applications.

To illustrate, let us look at two examples. (i) Using our work on stochastic differential equations, in the paper published in [Journal of Chemical Physics (2016)], we developed algorithms that outperform the well-known procedures in the literature for chemical reaction processes involving a large number of molecular species and reactions. (ii) For many ecological and biological systems, a long-standing and fundamental question is: What are the minimal conditions needed for  permanence of a population or for  long-term coexistence of interacting species. Focusing on environmental noise,our work [SIAM Journal on Applied Dynamics (2016), and SIAM Journal on Applied Mathematics (2016)] developed sharp sufficient and almost necessary conditions completely classifying the permanence and extinction for epidemic models and bio-diversity when random disturbances are taken into consideration. It is conceivable such effort will have further impact in the future.

b. Other products that have resulted from the grant:

Thanks to the NSF support, in the past few years, substantial progress in the aforementioned topics has been made. The research outputs include one research monograph (2nd and much expanded edition) published in Springer's series Stochastic Modelling and Applied Probability, two monographs published in Science Press,  two other monographs published in Springer's series Briefs in Mathematics, and numerous refereed journal papers published in prestigious journals of applied mathematics and engineering. The research results have also been dissimilated through conferences and seminar presentations.

c.  Other information that would be of interest to the public: 

The research involved participation of graduate students;it included undergraduate student research projects as well.During the funding period of the grant, eleven Ph.D. students have been completed their dissertations under the PI's direction. They have been well placed in such positions as Tenure-Track Assistant Professor at University of Alabama, Tuscaloosa, Ball State University; Senior Lecturer, Hue University, Vietnam; Postdoctoral Fellow at University of Kansas, Tufts University; Lecturer, Wayne State University, Ball State University; Research Scientists at Ford Motor Research (2 Ph.D. recipients), GE Global Research,  J.P. Morgan Chase,  and Graham Media Group etc. The student who joined Graham Media also had previous postdoctoral  fellow position at the University of Delaware, received the National Research Council award, and used the grant as a postdoctoral fellow at an Air Force Research Laboratory. 

In addition, ten master students have completed their master's essays under the PI's direction. Most of them are working in the local industry or community colleges etc.

Moreover, several undergraduate students conducted their undergraduate research under the PI's direction. Their research findings were presented at the Wayne State University's Undergraduate Conferences. Three undergraduate research students of thePI, continued (or soon to start) their Ph.D. works at the UC Santa Barbara, the University of Michigan, and Oakland University, in Computer Science, Physics, and Mathematics, respectively.


By integrating the proposed research with teaching and studenttraining, the work contributes to the further development of mathematical theory and the improvement of mathematics education.
